conbody.p: NCC CNF is installed with several Helm charts managing its set of container types. All of these Helm charts can be configured to deploy into a single namespace for the entire NCC CNF. Operators can configure this namespace.

An operator might choose to deploy their ME pairs in strategic locations throughout their network. Then for the two SMs, they might decide to deploy an SM into one of the sites already selected to also deploy an ME. For the SM and ME to both exist in that same Kubernetes cluster, they must be configured with separate namespaces (and non-conflicting ports) to ensure both CNFs can co-exist seamless without conflict. For more information, see CNF Installation and Update Guide in the NCC documentation set.

The exception is if the SM and ME are deployed as an Integrated CNF, with both functions combined into that single CNF. In that case, the entire CNF, including both SM, ME, and common pods, resides in a single namespace.

The initial NCC CNF version is targeted for deployment into an operator's existing Kubernetes environment. The operator provides various infrastructure components such as Kubernetes, service mesh, various telemetry components, interfaces to northbound OSS, and so on. NCC follows standard best practices and is therefore generic and flexible by nature and in future versions it will be certified for deployment in a wide variety of environments.
